entry.title: On Skill Specialization and Personal Growth
entry.content:
On Skill Specialization and Personal Growth

- Apr 19, 2014-

People often wonder what they should learn in life with respect to their career and goals. I’d like to offer one rather broad approach.

The internet offers an explosion of information. More than any one (wo)man could ever learn within a lifetime. It also offers more opportunity to learn than ever before. There just is no reason why someone cannot pursue a field that interests them anymore. This is especially true in software and tech. I’ve been told that some people are not capable enough. However, the only limitation is one’s own motivation. People who know me, know that I’m the last person to have unconditional faith in the human race. And this is something even I, believe that anyone can do.

Then what should you learn? You could ask what the most popular language is currently. There are people who have made careers solely as Java developers. Some of them are very good at what they do. Traditionally, broad spectrum knowledge indicates that specialists are good at large companies, and generalists are good at small startups.

I want to debunk this myth. In any situation, being exposed to only a single source of information can be dangeorous. Those that are accepting of new ideas prosper. Those that are set in their ways stagnate. The world is constantly changing, and you need to too.

Software Engineering Specialization

The same idea applies to learning how to be a software engineer. Every community around a single programming language has a set of best practices, and beliefs that they hold dear. Certain design patterns are more popular in one language than another. Different languages use different concurrency models, programming paradigms, type systems, data structures, and on and on. Learning a language from each programming paradigm will expand your toolbox, expose you to methodology pros and cons, and end up making you a better programmer in your first language than you were before.

When you are exposed to the multiple facets of software engineering, something happens. You are able to learn new languages faster. This is important today. Different problems will have a different best solution. By only knowing a single programming language you are restricting yourself to a limited set of problems, and limiting your flexibility to unforseen future changes.

Product Development Specialization

So great, learning multiple programming languages will make me a better programmer. However, just like specialization within software engineering may hold you back, so might specialization in just software engineering. I am of the opinion that every software engineer should learn a little bit of a field outside of engineering. What exactly depends.

For me, I’ve spent time learning product UI/UX. I cannot replace a UI/UX specialist. However, I did design this blog, chose the colors, and I drew the crappy beach pixel art (didn’t take very long) in the header. At the same time, I can put together a highly available, fault-tolerant server cluster, manage a database, write an api server, write a client, program a game, and mess around with html and css.

While I haven’t been the lead designer on a product (although I was a product manager for a short period of time), knowing a few design skills have been invaluable. It’s the difference between stopping work because art assets were exported incorrectly, versus opening up an image editor and fixing them yourself. It’s the difference between realizing that an app interaction sucks, versus the other guy not realizing the problem with blurry assets. In my opinion, every software engineer should know the differences between affordances and signifiers. If you do, you’ll find that code itself has usability, and you’ll write better software because of it.

Experience Specialization

Travel. It’s important. I’ve always enjoyed traveling to other countries and gaining new experiences. My last trip was a bouldering trip to Spain, and France. Recently, I was asked

Why would you want to go someplace else?

The same reasons why engineering, and product development branching are good also apply to your location. It can be argued that how good it is depends on where you live. Certain locations are exposed to a much more diverse set of ideas and experiences. But, you can be absolutely sure of benefit by traveling to other countries. It exposes you to new ways of thinking, new languages, and what varies between people from different areas versus what stays the same. All of these are becoming more important as the markets become increasingly global.

Conclusion

If you are content knowing only a single programming language, working in only one field, living in a small town 100 miles from the nearest city your entire life, and you have a choice, then there is nothing I can do. If you leave a comment, I may mail you a box of lawn darts to throw at small children while yelling, “Get off my lawn!”.

For me, I love building things. Building products today involves different parts working together, and it becomes useful to know a little bit about the parts adjacent to me. If your sole goal in life was to find a better algorithm for k-coloring, well, this advice is probably still useful.

entry.title: Voronoi Noise and Erlang, Nif, and Port performance comparison
entry.content:
Voronoi Noise and Erlang, Nif, and Port Performance Comparison

- Apr 14, 2014 -

I wanted some Voronoi noise generated from Erlang. I needed to know how I should generate the noise, and what the most efficient way of doing this from Erlang was. I knew about Erlang NIFs already (Native Implemented Function). I was already using several through third party libraries. What I did not know is if I needed a NIF.

If Erlang could get the job done, then using a NIF would be overkill. In order to help with future decisions, I first implemented a Voronoi noise algorithm in Erlang, then as a C NIF, then as a C Port. I measured the performance at each step of the way. Who knows, the communication overhead with C could be more expensive than the operation itself. I’ve experienced this before with V8, and JNI bindings.

Voronoi Noise

Voronoi noise is also called Worley noise. It creates these polygon-like patterns like the ones in the header image of this blog post. There are several algorithms for Voronoi noise in existence. I chose Steven Worley’s algorithm. I had the special case of wanting infinite Voronoi Noise, and it did not look like Fortune’s algorithm could support that. The added bonus is that the algorithm is simple.

I won’t go into too much depth about how the algorithm works. There are many articles on this topic, such as here. The basic idea is that the noise is generated in chunks. Each chunk randomly generates a number of points based on a poisson distribution. You also need to know the points for all neighboring chunks. Then at each pixel value, you calculate the distance to the closest point.

Erlang Implementation

For the Erlang implementation I first used arrays. Arrays in Erlang are supposed to have much more efficient random access than lists. It wasn’t until after I implemented the algorithm that I realized I could get away with sequential access. In which case, lists would have been much better. Good news, I implemented both. We can compare.

In addition to the main algorithm, I also implemented Knuth’s hashing function, a linear congruential random generator, and a way to calculate the probability of X in a poisson distribution given an average. The poission results are cached in a lookup table based on an average of 3 points per cube.

Here is the list version.

%% @doc generate the voronoi noise at chunk CX, CY
-spec voronoi_chunk(CX, CY) -> Distances when
      CX        :: integer(),
      CY        :: integer(),
      Distances :: [[any()]].
voronoi_chunk(CX, CY) ->
    Data = lists:duplicate(?CHUNK_SIZE, lists:duplicate(?CHUNK_SIZE, 7777)),
    Coors = voronoi_neighbor_points(CX, CY),
    map_voronoi_distances(Coors, Data).

%% @doc generate voronoi coordinates for all neighbors and self chunk
-spec voronoi_neighbor_points(CX, CY) -> Coordinates when
      CX                :: integer(),
      CY                :: integer(),
      Coordinates       :: [{integer(), integer()}].
voronoi_neighbor_points(CX, CY) ->
    %% for is a utility fn that performs an action over multiple lists.
    %% it gives you nested looping functionality.
    CoorLists = catchvar_util:for(fun(I, J) ->
                                   lists:map(fun({X, Y}) -> 
                                                 {X + (I * ?CHUNK_SIZE),
                                                  Y + (J * ?CHUNK_SIZE)}
                                             end,
                                             voronoi_points(CX + I, CY + J))
                               end,
                               [lists:seq(-1, 1),
                                lists:seq(-1, 1)]),
    lists:flatten(CoorLists).

%% @doc generate voronoi coordinates for a single chunk
-spec voronoi_points(CX, CY) -> Coordinates when
      CX                :: integer(),
      CY                :: integer(),
      Coordinates       :: [{integer(), integer()}].
voronoi_points(CX, CY) ->
    Hash = knuth_hash(CX * 7 + CY * 13),
    NumPoints = poisson_table(lcg_rand(Hash)),
    Coors = lists:map(fun(X) -> X / ?LCG_M * ?CHUNK_SIZE end, 
                      catchvar_util:iterate(fun catchvar_noise:lcg_rand/1, 
                                         Hash, 
                                         NumPoints * 2)),
    list_to_coors(Coors).

%% @doc convert flat list into coordinate tuples
-spec list_to_coors(List) -> Coordinates when
      List              :: [integer()],
      Coordinates       :: [{integer(), integer()}].
list_to_coors([]) -> [];
list_to_coors([X, Y | Tail]) ->
    [{X, Y} | list_to_coors(Tail)].

%% @doc calculates closest distance against coordinates
-spec map_voronoi_distances(Coordinates, Data) -> UpdatedData when
      Coordinates       :: [{integer(), integer()}],
      Data              :: [[integer()]],
      UpdatedData       :: [[integer()]].
map_voronoi_distances([], Data) -> Data;
map_voronoi_distances([{X, Y} | Tail], Data) ->
    Data2 = vd({X, Y}, 0, 0, Data),
    map_voronoi_distances(Tail, Data2).

vd(_, _, _, []) -> [];
vd(P, I, J, [Head | Tail]) ->
    [sd(P, I, J, Head) | vd(P, I + 1, 0, Tail)].

sd(_, _, _, []) -> [];
sd({X, Y} = P, I, J, [Head | Tail]) ->
    Dist = catchvar_util:dist(X, Y, I, J),
    if Dist < Head ->
           [Dist | sd(P, I, J+1, Tail)];
       true ->
           [Head | sd(P, I, J+1, Tail)]
    end.

Calling voronoi_chunk with chunk coordinates creates a single chunk. The following image was created by generating 36 individual chunks (Larger in real life).

Looks pretty good to me. I was satisfied. The only problem is that it was taking a long time. I thought that it might be the image library. A 600x600 image is a fair amount of pixels to generate. So I used tc:timer to measure the amount of time it took to generate the data, and then calculated min, max, mean, and average of 36 chunks being generated. Here are the results.

  • Erlang Array Performance Range: 161428 - 354945 mics Median: 226675 mics Average: 233696 mics
  • Erlang List Performance Range: 83625 - 200815 mics Median: 125300 mics Average: 129581 mics

It is true, that I am iterating over 360,000 elements. There are also inefficiencies in my algorithm, such as repeatedly generating neighboring points. But, ouch. Note that these measurements are in microseconds. On average it was taking 234ms per chunk with my Erlang array version. Luckily, it was much better with the list version. It only took 130ms on average. However, I wanted to do better. On to NIFs.

NIF implementation

I would prefer to avoid using C if the situation suits it. But this seemed like a good opportunity to give NIFs a test drive. NIFs are the fastest way to interop with C through Erlang. They come with one big downside. A crash in a NIF means the Erlang emulator crashes. Lets see if they are worth it.

First let’s look at the C code.

#include "erl_nif.h" // need to include

static int load(ErlNifEnv* env, void** priv, ERL_NIF_TERM load_info) {
    return 0;
}

static int reload(ErlNifEnv* env, void** priv, ERL_NIF_TERM load_info) {
    return 0;
}

static int upgrade(ErlNifEnv* env, void** priv, void** old_priv, ERL_NIF_TERM load_info) {
    return 0;
}

static void unload(ErlNifEnv* env, void* priv) {
    return;
}

This is a little bit of boiler plate code. The include file has lots of things we need to interface with Erlang. All the rest of the functions are not strictly needed, but they are used for code upgrading, etc.

static ErlNifFunc nif_funcs[] = {
    {"voronoi_chunk", 2, voronoi_nif}
};

This specifies what functions are being exported to Erlang. Here I’m saying I want to access a function named voronoi_chunk with an arity of 2, and the C function is named voronoi_nif.

static ERL_NIF_TERM voronoi_nif(ErlNifEnv* env, int argc, const ERL_NIF_TERM argv[]) {
    int cx, cy, i, j;

    // read parameters
    if (!enif_get_int(env, argv[0], &cx)) {
        return enif_make_badarg(env);
    }

    if (!enif_get_int(env, argv[1], &cy)) {
        return enif_make_badarg(env);
    }

    // voronoi chunk
    unsigned dists[100][100];

    for (i = 0; i < 100; i++) {
        for (j = 0; j < 100; j++) {
            dists[i][j] = 7777;
        }
    }

    voronoi_chunk(dists, cx, cy);

    // convert dists to erl term
    ERL_NIF_TERM erl_dists[100][100];
    ERL_NIF_TERM erl_dists_out[100];

    for (i = 0; i < 100; i++) {
        for (j = 0; j < 100; j++) {
            erl_dists[i][j] = enif_make_uint(env, dists[i][j]);
        }

        erl_dists_out[i] = enif_make_list_from_array(env, erl_dists[i], 100);
    }

    return enif_make_list_from_array(env, erl_dists_out, 100);
}


ERL_NIF_INIT(catchvar_noise_nif, nif_funcs, load, reload, upgrade, unload);

This is the bulk of the erlang and C interfacing. First, I load two integer arguments into cx, and cy. Then, I execute my custom C voronoi noise. Next, I need to load the data into Erlang data structures. This is messy, but it was the only way I could get a multi-dimensional array to work.

Next, I create two arrays of ERL_NIF_TERM. I load them with the data from the dists array, converting unsigned ints with enif_make_unit. The tricky part is that I have a separate single dimension array I use to represent the multi-dimensional array called erl_dists_out. Once I have erl_dists_out I can use enif_make_list_from_array as the return value. It’s not the most inviting interface, but you can figure it out through the documentation.

Next, you need to have an Erlang module that will load the C code as a .so file.

-module(catchvar_noise_nif).
-export([voronoi_chunk/2]).
-on_load(init/0).

-define(LIBNAME, noise).

voronoi_chunk(_, _) ->
    not_loaded(?LINE).

init() ->
    SoName = catchvar_util:get_c_path(?LIBNAME),
    erlang:load_nif(SoName, 0).

not_loaded(Line) ->
    exit({not_loaded, [{module, ?MODULE},
                {line, Line}]}).

Short, and sweet. I separated get_c_path out into a utility module. It looks like this.

%% @doc get path to priv binaries
-spec get_c_path(Name) -> Path when
      Name      :: string() | atom,
      Path      :: string().
get_c_path(Name) ->
    case code:priv_dir(catchvar) of
        {error, bad_name} ->
            case filelib:is_dir(filename:join(["..", priv])) of
                true ->
                    filename:join(["..", priv, Name]);
                _ ->
                    filename:join([priv, Name])
            end;
        Dir ->
            filename:join([Dir, Name])
    end.

Credit for this snippet goes to here.

If you are using rebar, add this to rebar.config in order to compile your c program with rebar compile.

{port_specs, [
    {"priv/noise.so", ["c_src/noise.c"]}
]}.

Now to run it using the same test case, and see our results.

  • Erlang NIF Range: 2053 - 14494 mics Median: 2740 mics Average: 3599 mics

Hurray! The average time spent per chunk went down from 130ms to 4ms. We had one outlier that reached 14ms, but our median is less than 3ms. This is something I can work with. The only scary thing is that a crash will crash Erlang. I wanted to know what the performance would be like if I programmed in C, but in a safer manner. On to C ports.

C Port Implementation

With NIFs a crash will bring everything down. This is not the case with a C port. Erlang ports are not specific to C. They can interop with any language you want. The way it works is that you have an Erlang process that communicates to a separate process running your program in another language. The other process is not an Erlang process, but an OS process. Communication is done on the byte level. Erlang only provides facilities to help with the various protocols.

First, the C code. Much of this comes from the Erlang tutorial.

typedef unsigned char byte;

int read_cmd(byte *buf) {
  int len;

  if (read_exact(buf, 2) != 2)
    return(-1);
  len = (buf[0] << 8) | buf[1];
  return read_exact(buf, len);
}

int write_cmd(byte *buf, int len) {
  byte li;

  li = (len >> 8) & 0xff;
  write_exact(&li, 1);
  
  li = len & 0xff;
  write_exact(&li, 1);

  return write_exact(buf, len);
}

int read_exact(byte *buf, int len) {
  int i, got=0;

  do {
    if ((i = read(0, buf+got, len-got)) <= 0)
      return(i);
    got += i;
  } while (got<len);

  return(len);
}

int write_exact(byte *buf, int len) {
  int i, wrote = 0;

  do {
    if ((i = write(1, buf+wrote, len-wrote)) <= 0)
      return (i);
    wrote += i;
  } while (wrote<len);

  return (len);
}

This is boiler plate code. It provides methods for reading and writing bytes.

int main() {
    int fn;
    int i, j;
    byte buf[10000];

    while (read_cmd(buf) > 0) {
        fn = buf[0];

        if (fn == 1) {
            unsigned dists[100][100];
            int cx = 0;
            int cy = 0;

            cx += buf[1] << 24;
            cx += buf[2] << 16;
            cx += buf[3] << 8;
            cx += buf[4] << 0;

            cy += buf[5] << 24;
            cy += buf[6] << 16;
            cy += buf[7] << 8;
            cy += buf[8] << 0;

            for (i = 0; i < 100; i++) {
                for (j = 0; j < 100; j++) {
                    dists[i][j] = 7777;
                } 
            }

            voronoi_chunk(dists, cx, cy);
            for (i = 0; i < 100; i++) {
                for (j = 0; j < 100; j++) {
                    buf[i * 100 + j] = dists[i][j]; 
                } 
            }
        } else if (fn == 2) {
            unsigned int hash = knuth_hash(1 * 7 + 66 * 13);

            // big-endian
            buf[0] = (hash >> 24) & 0xff;
            buf[1] = (hash >> 16) & 0xff;
            buf[2] = (hash >> 8)  & 0xff;
            buf[3] = (hash >> 0)  & 0xff;
        }

        write_cmd(buf, 10000);
    }

    return 0;
}

This is the bulk of communication. If you cringed at the thought of converting types between Erlang and C in NIFs, then you’re probably not doing too well now. A single byte is read to indicate what function should be called. Next, you can read any arguments you passed along. In this case I am reading two 4 byte integers. Next I call voronoi_chunk, and store the data as a flattened multi-dimensional array in buffer. Then I use write_cmd to send it back to Erlang.

-module(catchvar_noise_port).
-export([start/1, 
         init/1, 
         voronoi_chunk/2]).

start(ExtPrg) ->
    spawn(?MODULE, init, [ExtPrg]).

init(ExtPrg) ->
    ExtPath = catchvar_util:get_c_path(ExtPrg),
    register(catchvar_noise_port_c, self()),
    process_flag(trap_exit, true),
    Port = open_port({spawn, ExtPath},
                     [{packet, 2}]),
    loop(Port).

loop(Port) ->
    receive
        {call, Caller, Msg} ->
            Port ! {self(), {command, encode(Msg)}},
            receive
                {Port, {data, Data}} ->
                    Caller ! {catchvar_noise_port_c, decode(Data)}
            end,
            loop(Port)
    end.

call_port(Msg) ->
    catchvar_noise_port_c ! {call, self(), Msg},
    receive
        {catchvar_noise_port_c, Result} ->
            Result
    end.

encode({voronoi_chunk, CX, CY}) -> [1, <<CX:32/integer>>, <<CY:32/integer>>];

decode(X) when length(X) =:= 10000 ->
    Result = lists:foldl(fun(I, Acc) -> 
                    [lists:sublist(X, I * 100 + 1, 100) | Acc]
                end,
                [],
                lists:seq(0, 99)),
    lists:reverse(Result);
decode(X) when length(X) =:= 4 ->
    <<Result:32/integer>> = list_to_binary(X),
    Result.

voronoi_chunk(CX, CY) ->
    call_port({voronoi_chunk, CX, CY}).

This all starts off with a call like this. 

catchvar_noise_port:start("extprg").

This spawns a process created from the init function. The new process sets itself as a system process, registers itself, and connects to the port at ExtPath. {packet, 2} specifies the protocol. In this case, it means the first 2 bytes will be the length of data. This is abstracted out in the above C code.

After that we start listening for messages. When we call 

catchvar_noise_port:voronoi_chunk(0, 65).

from another process it sends a message to our newly create process. This process will in turn communicate with the C port. The encode and decode functions handle passing data. encode returns a list of integers. Each element is a single integer byte, but you can also pass in binaries. decode receives a normal list where each element is a byte.

I did this quick and dirty. You could also use gen_server to clean this up. If you’re using rebar, add this to your rebar.config to build with rebar compile.

{port_specs, [
    {"priv/extprg", ["c_src/foo.c"]}
]}.

Then we can run with the same test case, and see our results!

  • Erlang C Port Range: 12392 - 86549 mics Median: 17515 mics Average: 20838 mics

That’s not too shabby. We have protection since a C crash will only crash the linked process. Plus, we are still using C, so we get a speed up. 20ms vs 130ms. That is over a 6x speed up vs plain Erlang.

Conclusion

All of these options have their trade-offs. By using Erlang you get to program in Erlang. This typically means much faster development times than when using C. The downside is speed. Most people are aware that Erlang is not the choice for number-crunching calculations.

By using NIFs, you get speed. Really fast speed. The downside is a lack of fault-tolerance. We’re back to relying solely on defensive programming. Development time will also be slower, and we need to convert data between C and Erlang all the time. Also, word on the street is that NIFs can possibly be dangerous if execution is taking more a than a few milliseconds. It may be possible for the Erlang scheduler to start putting scheduled processes to sleep when they shouldn’t be. I’m unsure if these problems still persist in the latest Erlang version, but it’s something to be aware of.

By using C Ports, you get an alternative somewhere in the middle. It’s pretty fast, but not blazing fast. Development time is still slow, but you get a little bit of fault-tolerance. Using this information should give you a better idea of which option is right for you.

Additional Reading

  • Polygon Map Generation
  • DwarfCore Terrain Generation
  • Cell Noise
  • Measuring Erlang Execution Time
  • Erlang NIFs
  • Computing Voronoi Diagram Robustly

entry.title: Defensive and Fail-Fast Programming the Right Way
entry.content:
Defensive and Fail-Fast Programming the Right Way

- Apr 4, 2014 -

Programmers program errors. You need to handle errors. Every major language has constructs for handling errors. Two guidelines that many try to follow are defensive programming, and fail-fast programming. The problems are that everyone has a different definition, and our choice of error handling should depend on our goals.

I want to take a look at what each method means, and how they should be used. I’ll also try to examine each method from the perspective of multiple languages.

First, we need to define how we want our program will behave. In 2014 users have strong expections of their programs. The internet has created an always on environment. Programs should always work. Users will not tolerate status 500 server error pages. They do not want cryptic error messages. This means no crashing. When a user is expecting a response from the program, errors should be handled gracefully. Make the user aware an error occured, then keep on chugging. We want to fix errors fast. So, we need to be aware of when they occur. If we can achieve all these goals, then we’ll be using user focused programming. Let’s look at defensive programming first.

Defensive Programming

Some people hate it. Some people love it. If you hate it, it may be because people are misusing it and claiming glory in the name of defensive programming. In theory it basically means this.

Defend against the impossible, because the impossible will happen [1].

In practice is applies to a broad smorgasbord of things. It means doing whatever it takes to prevent the application from crashing. It mostly applies to validating function arguments, and using one-size fits all syntax.

Verifying function arguments

This is mostly what comes to mind when someone refers to defensive programming. It means that a function should have defined behaviour for all possible inputs. If a function cannot handle an input, then it should throw an exception.

// no defensive programming
public List<String> getFriendNames(User user) {
    List<User> users = user.getFriends();
    List<String> names = new ArrayList<String>();

    for (User user : users) {
        names.add(user.getName());
    }

    return names;
}

The problem above is that there are numerous opportunities for null pointer exceptions. In addition, we may get nulls in our return list. An incorrect attempt at defensive programming may look like this:

// bad
public List<String> getFriendNames(User user) {
    List<String> names = new ArrayList<String>();

    if (user != null) {
        List<User> users = user.getFriends();

        if (users != null) {
            for (User user : users) {
                String name = user.getName();
                names.add(name);
            } 
        }
    }

    return names;
}

This is where people have the right to complain. I do not consider this defensive programming. This is sweep under the rug programming. If an error occurs you won’t know. Defensive programming would look like this:

// better
public List<String> getFriendNames(User user) throws InvalidFriendListException {
    if (user != null) {
        List<User> users = user.getFriends();
        List<String> names = new ArrayList<String>();

        if (users != null) {
            for (User user : users) {
                String name = user.getName();
                names.add(name == null ? "" : name);
            } 
        } else {
            throw new InvalidFriendListException();
        }

    } else {
        throw new InvalidFriendListException();
    }

    return names;
}

This code works for valid input, and will throw an exception for invalid input. Now we know an error occured and can do something about it. However, this is kind of hard. It’s bloated. Just look at how many Exception subclasses exist in large projects. Can you really expect everyone on your team to do this in every function? Maybe you could. Here is how this might look in Clojure.

;; user is a map
;; ex.
;; {:friends [{:name "Steven"}
;;            {:name "Jake"}
;;            {:name nil}]}
(defn get-friend-names [user]
    (if-let [result (remove nil? (map :name (:friends user)))]
        result
        (throw (InvalidFriendListException.))))

You still need to manually throw an exception. Alternatively, many clojure users may just handle nil as the return value of get-friend-names. nil is the null value in Clojure. This works because many Clojure functions can safely handle nil. That is kind of sweet. However, null pointer exceptions still happen. Number ops or Java interop can cause null pointer exceptions, and in actual Clojure code there still tends to be an abundance of if statements checking argument values. Here is how this would look in Erlang.

-module(test).
-export([get_friend_names/1]).

get_friend_names({user, {friends, [{name, Name}|T]}}) ->
    [Name | get_friend_names({user, {friends, T}})];
get_friend_names({user, {friends, []}}) -> 
    [].

%% add me to throw a custom error meant to be caught
%% get_friend_names(X) -> throw({invalid_friends_list, X}).

That’s it. We define the valid inputs that will work. Any other inputs throw an exception. Some people learn to hate the exception thrown here because it happens often. Remember, this is doing exactly what all that crusty Java code did. You’re getting defensive programming for free!

Using one-size fits all syntax

This is a very language dependent style of programming. I won’t spend much time on it. It means using syntax that will avoid errors. This can include not using if statements without curly braces, one return statement per function, or the leading comma syntax in JavaScript (which I don’t use).

var obj = {a = 4
          ,b = 5
          ,c = 10
          ,d = []}; // added this line later

// vs

var obj = {a: 4,
           b: 5,
           c: 10 // doh! missing a comma
           d: []};

Fail-fast Programming

Fail-fast programming is probably best described by someone else’s quote.

whereby an application or system service terminates itself immediately upon encountering an error [2].

Sounds pretty scary. It’s an old idea. Some people like it because it makes bugs very apparent. This may have been acceptable in the olden days (10 years ago), but we want high-availablity.

In the context of Java I do not see this being very applicable since often times if the main thread dies you crash.

In the context of Erlang and highly concurrent languages it is more applicable. It is not mutually exclusive with defensive programming, and can be layered on top to achieve fault-tolerance. This is because Erlang programs generally consist of many processes. Erlang provides very good mechanisms for detecting when a process crashes. In the event of process A crashing, process B can clean up any errors and restart A. In addition, supervisors allow for flexible configuration with different restart strategies. For example, you can have a supervisor monitor 3 processes. When one dies you can choose to restart all 3, just the one that died, or restart all processes that depended on the killed process. You can also set limits on how many restarts can occur within a specified time limit.

Erlang’s ability to handle process errors allows for many benefits.

  • Error handling is separated from your core logic. This creates a sepration of concerns.
  • Fixing an error is generally much simpler by failing-fast. Sometimes when an unexpected error happens all you can do is say, crap… but wait! We can restart the process and keep on chugging without crashing. This leads to fault-tolerance.
  • Error handling can be distributed across machines for free.

Not every error needs to crash the process. Fail-fast can work in tandem with defensive programming. Erlang also provides try ... catchs. Simple errors that can be handled, should be handled. Fail-fast may also not be appropriate in all areas of the program. It is very similar to the trade off between consistency and availability. If you absolutely cannot lose state, it may be better to lean more towards defensive programming.

One worry is that we die, we restart, and then we just keep doing it all over again. I don’t see too much wrong with this. Imagine you’re using a program and an internal error occurs. A process crashes, and gets restarted. Your program keeps running. That’s good. This problem is not much different than repeatedly catching the same error over and over. If you’re unable to fix the problem by restarting the entire process it’s hard to see how additional logic in a try ... catch would help.

Note: I’ve also seen fail-fast refer to throwing exceptions rather than allowing undefined behaviour. In this sense, it is similar, or the same, to what I described as the correct way of doing defensive programming.

Not finished

With defensive and fail-fast programming we have the makings of a well-defined fault-tolerant program. However, a full error handling methodology is incomplete without two points.

  • Unexpected behaviour should be presented to the user in a graceful manner. In a client-server architecture this may mean having your api return an error code. The important aspect is that user experience is minimally affected. No cryptic error codes. Friendly dialogs that inform the user of the error, while still allowing continuing execution seems to work best.
  • We code with defensive and fail-fast programming to make the program aware of these errors. Once we’re aware we can handle them. We as developers, also need to be aware so we can fix them. The best way I’ve found is to log errors to a source for later access. On the server, this could be log files that get rotated to s3. On the client, there are tools for sending errors to a managable location. In addition, there are various ways to send notifications when an error occurs. Email is the simplest way.

Conclusion

The main conclusion I come to is that defensive programming and fail-fast programming are confusing terms. The above descriptions should allow for better discussion between developers. First ask, “What do you mean?”, when someone brings up one of these terms. User-focused programming is an all encompassing term, but will probably be mangled as requirements over time change.

However, at least a few definitions do describe what we want. We should code in a manner that is not suspectible to breakage if the code changes. Our functions should have defined behaviour for a set of inputs. Undefined behaviour throws an exception. We should handle these exceptions. In Java, handling means using try ... catchs. In Erlang, handling could mean using try ... catchs if we need to maintain state, or failing the process to be restarted in order to gain the many benefits it presents. Unexpected behaviour should be presented to the user in a graceful manner, while still allowing the application to run. In all cases our errors should be logged to a persistent source.

If you have different goals than a highly available, user-friendly program, where we can easily find and fix bugs, then different error handling methods would be reasonable. Remember, these methods are not a replacement for automation, and developer testing.

Additional Reading

  • [1] Defensive Programming
  • [2] Fail Fast
  • Does defensive programming deserve
  • Rules for defensive C programming

entry.title: Cocos2d-x HTTPS and your own certificate authority
entry.content:
Cocos2d-x HTTPS and your own certificate authority

- Mar 25, 2014 -

Security in mobile games is usually left by the wayside. Usually, it’s just the lowest priority item on the list when it comes to getting a game out by a deadline. After the fact, you can ask anyone if the game should have security feature X and they’ll be shocked that it doesn’t already exist. Ask the same person before a deadline if you should have the same security feature, or a sparkling unicorn riding across the bottom of the settings page, and they’ll choose the sparking unicorn unless they’re a security nut.

This isn’t always entirely without merit. However, in the context of a real-time multiplayer game where players constantly interact with each other security becomes more important. You don’t want one bad seed ruining the experience for all the other players. Using HTTPS is one aspect that can improve the security of your game. We don’t need to buy an expensive certificate from a certificate authority either. If you’re distributing a mobile game you can distribute the certificate chain with the game.

Create your own certificate authority

This is the part that I had the most trouble with. There are tutorials galore out there, however the ones I ran into failed to provide certificates that actually worked. Hopefully it can be a little easier for you. Use easycert openssl on github to create your certificates.

$ curl -O https://raw.github.com/jsermeno/kerl/master/easycert
$ chmod a+x easycert

Then add this file to your path. You can edit your ~/.bash_profile and do something like this:

export PATH=$PATH:~/Workspace/path/easycert

Next we’ll create a necessary configuration file. Make any necessary changes to the following config and copy it into your shell.

$ cat > ~/.easycertrc << EOF
EASYCERT_COUNTRY="US"
EASYCERT_STATE="California"
EASYCERT_LOCALITY="Mountain View"
EASYCERT_ORGANIZATION="Catchvar"
EASYCERT_UNIT="Studio"
EASYCERT_COMMON_NAME="localhost"
EASYCERT_EMAIL="youremailaddress@gmail.com"
EASYCERT_UNSTRUCTURED="Catchvar"
EOF

When a client makes a request it will check the domain against the EASYCERT_COMMON_NAME property so make sure this property reflects your own domain. For development, localhost works. You’ll need seperate certificates for production. The other important property is EASYCERT_ORGANIZATION. You just need to know that this must be the same among all your certificates. Easycert will do that for you, so don’t worry.

$ easycert create-all ~/.ca

This command tells easycert to create your certificates at ~/.ca. It will create a root certificate, an intermediate certificate, and a server certificate. The root certificate and the intermediate certificate make up the certificate chain. The certificate chain will be what clients use to verify your server.

You’ll be prompted several times during this process. You’ll be asked for two separate passphrases for the root and intermediate keys. You will need to enter each passpharse twice to verify that it’s really what you wanted to enter.

Generating directory structure... /Users/catchvar/.cert
Generating directory structure... /Users/catchvar/.cert/intermediate
Generating ca root key...
Generating RSA private key, 4096 bit long modulus
................................................................................................................................................................++
.....................................................................................................++
e is 65537 (0x10001)
Enter pass phrase for /Users/catchvar/.cert/private/ca.key.pem:
Verifying - Enter pass phrase for /Users/catchvar/.cert/private/ca.key.pem:

When generating the certificates you’ll need to re-enter these passphrases.

Enter pass phrase for /Users/catchvar/.cert/private/ca.key.pem:

Then you’ll be asked to confirm the certificate info. The defaults will be what you entered into the configuration above. If you want to use the defaults just press enter and quickly get through that section.

You are about to be asked to enter information that will be incorporated
into your certificate request.
What you are about to enter is what is called a Distinguished Name or a DN.
There are quite a few fields but you can leave some blank
For some fields there will be a default value,
If you enter '.', the field will be left blank.
-----
Country Name (2 letter code) [US]:
State or Province Name (full name) [California]:
Locality Name (eg, city) [Mountain View]:
Organization Name (eg, company) [Catchvar]:
Organizational Unit Name (eg, section) [Studio]:
Common Name (eg, YOUR name) [localhost]:
Email Address [youremailaddress@gmail.com]:
generating intermediate key...
Generating RSA private key, 4096 bit long modulus
.......................++
...........................++
e is 65537 (0x10001)

You’ll need to to the same serveral times. Once for each certificate that is generated. When asked if you want to sign the certificate and commit just type y. The end will look like this.

1 out of 1 certificate requests certified, commit? [y/n]y
Write out database with 1 new entries
Data Base Updated
Verifying server certificate...{}
/Users/jsermeno/.cert/intermediate/certs/localhost.cert.pem: OK
done.

Now you can get the paths for where your certificates are stored.

$ easycert find ~/.ca
ca:                /Users/catchvar/.ca/certs/ca.cert.pem
intermediate:      /Users/catchvar/.ca/intermediate/certs/intermediate.cert.pem
server key:        /Users/catchvar/.ca/intermediate/private/localhost.key.pem
server:            /Users/catchvar/.ca/intermediate/certs/localhost.cert.pem
ca-chain:          /Users/catchvar/.ca/intermediate/certs/ca-chain.cert.pem
done.

Easycert verifies your certificates, but for added measure you can verify that your certificates are working properly with the following command.

openssl verify -verbose -purpose sslserver -CAfile ~/.ca/intermediate/certs/ca-chain.cert.pem ~/.ca/intermediate/certs/localhost.cert.pem

Use HTTPS with cocos2d-x

Currently I’m using cocos2d-x-3.0rc0. The version of libcurl included is 7.27.0 and is built with openssl. Beware. Newer versions of libcurl may be built with darwinssl, which is Apple’s native Secure Transport. This could be good. It means that you don’t have to include openssl. That means saving on the precious app size. However those versions of libcurl use the keychain on iOS and ignore the CURLOPT_CAINFO option. That means you can’t specify your own root certificate without using Apple’s APIs for adding certificates to the keychain.

To check what version of openssl you have you can use the following code.

curl = curl_easy_init();

curl_version_info_data *data = curl_version_info(CURLVERSION_NOW);
cocos2d::log("openssl version: %s", data->ssl_version);
cocos2d::log("version: %s", data->version);

Add ca-chain.cert.pem to your resources directory. I added mine at Project/ca-chain.cert.pem. The easiest way to make a HTTP request with cocos2d-x is to look at the samples and use the HttpClient class. Unfortunately, the HttpClient class does not currently support ssl. In fact it turns off ssl verification so that you can make requests to a https url with no certificate bundle. This certainly, is not secure.

Fortunately, it’s easy to add this functionality to HttpClient. In HttpClient.h add these lines under the public method section.

/** Enable ssl support **/
static void enableSSLCaInfo(std::string info);

/** Disable ssl support **/
static void disableSSLCaInfo();

In HttpClient.cpp we’ll add a string representing the path to your ca-chain.cert.pem file.

static std::string s_sslCaInfo; // string path to CURL_CAINFO value

And the methods for changing this string.

void HttpClient::enableSSLCaInfo(std::string info)
{
    s_sslCaInfo = info;
}

void HttpClient::disableSSLCaInfo()
{
    s_sslCaInfo.clear();
}

In the method configureCURL you’ll find these lines.

curl_easy_setopt(handle, CURLOPT_SSL_VERIFYPEER, 0L);
curl_easy_setopt(handle, CURLOPT_SSL_VERIFYHOST, 0L);

These lines disable ssl verification. Change them to these lines.

if (s_sslCaInfo.empty()) {
        curl_easy_setopt(handle, CURLOPT_SSL_VERIFYPEER, 0L);
        curl_easy_setopt(handle, CURLOPT_SSL_VERIFYHOST, 0L);
} else {
    curl_easy_setopt(handle, CURLOPT_SSL_VERIFYPEER, 1L);
    curl_easy_setopt(handle, CURLOPT_SSL_VERIFYHOST, 2L);
    curl_easy_setopt(handle, CURLOPT_CAINFO, s_sslCaInfo.c_str());
}

This just says that if you set the s_sslCaInfo string then enable ssl verification and look for the certificate chain at this location. I’ve added a pull request for this in the latest cocos2d-x develop. Hopefully, it or some variant gets merged in after review. The alternative is to use curl manually to do your requests for ssl. This isn’t terrible, but why do that when HttpClient already offers so much functionality?

Make a Request

You can use the HttpClient to make a request from any class, but it needs to inherit from cocos2d::Layer.

In your header file include the following headers.

#include <string>
#include <iostream> // optional
#include "cocos2d.h"
#include "network/HttpClient.h"
#include "msgpack.hpp" // optional
#include "CCConsole.h" // optional

Add a public definition like the following.

class YourClass : public cocos2d::Layer {
public:

    void onCallback(cocos2d::network::HttpClient *sender, cocos2d::network::HttpResponse *response);

In your cpp file include the following headers and using declarations.

#include "HttpRequest.h"

USING_NS_CC;
using namespace cocos2d::network;

Now you need to enable ssl. This is where you specify the filepath to your cert. In order to get this to work on both iOS and android a little trickery is involved. I haven’t found a better solution as of yet. Warning: Not nice solution ahead.

auto sharedFileUtils = FileUtils::getInstance();
std::string ret;

if (CC_TARGET_PLATFORM == CC_PLATFORM_ANDROID) {
    std::string writablePath = sharedFileUtils->getWritablePath();
    if (!writablePath.empty()) {
        ret = writablePath.substr(0, writablePath.size() - 6) + "app_data/ca-chain.cert.pem";
    }
} else {
    ret = sharedFileUtils->fullPathForFilename("ca-chain.cert.pem");
}

cocos2d::network::HttpClient::enableSSLCaInfo(ret);

The reason for this code is that on iOS we can give curl a path from our Resources directory no problem. When libcurl opens the cert file it first calls into openssl, then eventually uses fopen to open the cert. Since on android our Resources directory will be inside the APK, it is inaccessible. This means we need to store our cert in our application data folder. This is internal storage that is allocated for each app. The path above will point to the correct place. But, you need to copy your cert from the Assets (Resources on android) folder to the application data folder. This can be done in the onCreate method of your Activity.

@Override
protected void onCreate(Bundle savedInstanceState) {
        // TODO Auto-generated method stub
        super.onCreate(savedInstanceState);

        OutputStream os = null;
        InputStream ims = null;

        try {
            AssetManager assets = this.getAssets();

            File path = this.getDir("data", 0);
            File certFile = new File(path, "ca-chain.pem");

            if (!certFile.exists()) {
                os = new FileOutputStream(certFile);
                ims = assets.open("ca-chain.pem");
                certFile.createNewFile();

                int read = 0;
                byte[] bytes = new byte[1024];

                while ((read = ims.read(bytes)) != -1) {
                    os.write(bytes, 0, read);
                }
            }
        } catch (IOException e) {
            Log.d("cocos2d-x", "Failed to create data cert!");
        } finally {
            close(ims);
            close(os);
        }

}

private void close(Closeable c) {
    if (c != null) {
        try {
            c.close();
        } catch (IOException e) {
            Log.d("cocos2d-x", "Failed to close closeable.");
        }
    }
}

Setup the request.

cocos2d::network::HttpRequest *request = new cocos2d::network::HttpRequest();
request->setUrl("https://localhost:8443");
request->setRequestType(cocos2d::network::HttpRequest::Type::POST);
request->setResponseCallback(this, httpresponse_selector(YourClass::onCallback));

My project uses MessagePack to post data. But any (char *) can be sent.

std::vector<std::string> postData;
postData.push_back("dataOne");
postData.push_back("dataTwo");

// msgpack data
msgpack::sbuffer sbuf;
msgpack::pack(&sbuf, postData);

Now you can set the data and send!

request->setRequestData(sbuf.data(), sbuf.size());
cocos2d::network::HttpClient::getInstance()->send(request);
request->release();

Just wait for your response.

void YourClass::onCallback(HttpClient *sender, HttpResponse *response) {
    if (!response) {
        cocos2d::log(no response.");
        return;
    }
    
    if (!response->isSucceed()) {
        cocos2d::log("response failed.");
        cocos2d::log("error buffer: %s", response->getErrorBuffer());
        return;
    }
    
    std::vector<char> *buffer = response->getResponseData();
    msgpack::unpacked msg;
    msgpack::unpack(&msg, (const char*) &(*buffer)[0], buffer->size());
    msgpack::object obj = msg.get();
    
    std::cout << obj << std::endl;
    
    std::vector<std::string> parsedResponse;
    obj.convert(&parsedResponse);
}

If you used MessagePack your data is in the parsedResponse vector. Otherwise your response will be in the buffer vector as a series of chars.

Hopefully, this post will make someone’s game more secure. You can double check that everything is working by creating a second set of certificates. Use that set of certificates on your server and when you try using the ca-chain cert from the first set you should get an error.

Disclaimer: I am not a security expert, just a security-conscious everything engineer. Use at your own risk.

P.S. If you do not want to create your own certificate authority, and just want to access https://www.google.com, you can use the ca bundle provided from the curl website. Here is where you can download cacert.pem. This bundle is converted from Mozilla’s CA cert bundle.

entry.title: Setup Riak and Erlang Client on Mac OS X
entry.content:
Setup Riak and Erlang Client on Mac OS X

- Mar 16, 2014 -

In the past I’ve been a big fan of PostgreSQL. It’s rock solid and performant. I’ve used it to scale to hundreds of thousands of users without even coming close to breaking a sweat.

The downside is that horizontal scaling is a pain. That typically means that you end up scaling vertically as long as you can. In addition, you don’t get availability and fault-tolerance for free. It requires extra time and work.

I wanted a database that emphasized availability, fault-tolerance, and scalability with little cost to the developer. As an indie game developer this may lead to reduced costs since an equivalent larger machine is usually much more expensive than several smaller machines. Riak’s masterless design was appealing to me, and it looked like it fit my needs better than anything else out there. Of course, when choosing a new technology there is always a chance you’ll regret it, but there is only one way to find out!

I found the documentation for Riak to be pretty good. However, there were a couple of gotchas. I found people with the same problem who were unable to find an answer around the various corners of google search, so I thought I’d make this short post on how to setup Riak from source.

You can refer to Installing From Source and the Quickstart from the Riak site for the most up to date versions and instructions. This post assumes you already have the Xcode tools from the Apple Develop’s Website.

Let’s get the source code.

wget http://s3.amazonaws.com/downloads.basho.com/riak/1.4/1.4.8/riak-1.4.8.tar.gz
tar zxvf riak-1.4.8.tar.gz

Build Erlang

Now we need to build it. This is where we’ll add a few additional steps. First, you need a specific version of Erlang (R15B01), and it also needs to be built as 64-bit. I’m using kerl to manage my erlang versions and it has been working out pretty great so far. It’s a simple version manager similar to nvm or rbenv for node and ruby respectively, if you have ever used those.

curl -O https://raw.github.com/spawngrid/kerl/master/kerl
chmod a+x kerl

Then you need to add it to your path. I have a directory called ~/Workspace/path that I have setup just for occasions like this. That way I don’t have to add them to a place like /usr/bin. You can add this to your path by doing something like this.

mkdir ~/Workspace
mkdir ~/Workspace/path
mv kerl ~/Workspace/path

Edit your ~/.bash_profile to include this line:

export PATH=$PATH:$HOME/Workspace/path

In order to build our Erlang installations as 64-bit you need to create a ~/.kerlrc file with these contents:

KERL_CONFIGURE_OPTIONS="--disable-hipe --enable-smp-support --enable-threads
                        --enable-kernel-poll  --enable-darwin-64bit"

Now we can install Erlang R15B01.

kerl build R15B01 r15b01-64
kerl install r15b01-64 ~/erl/r15b01-64
. ~/erl/r15b01-64/activate

With kerl you’ll need to call that activate command for every shell you open. What I do is add . ~/erl/r15b01-64/activate to my ~/.bash_profile. The period in front of the command is important. Just calling activate without it won’t work. At this point you should be able to do

erl

and see an erlang shell that looks like this.

Erlang R15B01 (erts-5.9.1) [source] [64-bit] [smp:4:4] [async-threads:0] [kernel-poll:false]

Eshell V5.9.1  (abort with ^G)
1>

type halt(). to exit the shell.

Get GCC-4.2

Update: You don’t need gcc-4.2 for the latest riak on the latest Mac OS X. But I’ll leave this here in case someone wants it anyways for some reason.

The second thing we have to do is get gcc-4.2 and make sure we build riak with it.

brew tap homebrew/dupes
brew install apple-gcc42

We’re going to change the default xcode cc, gcc, c++, and g++. Make sure you backup their current locations. For reference these were my file locations.

cc      =>  /usr/bin/clang
gcc     =>  /usr/bin/gcc
c++     =>  /usr/bin/clang++
g++     =>  /usr/bin/g++

Again, make sure you back up the ones you need to.

mv /usr/bin/gcc /usr/bin/gcc.bk
mv /usr/bin/g++ /usr/bin/g++.bk

To point them to gcc-4.2 run these commands

cd /usr/bin
sudo rm cc gcc c++ g++
sudo ln -s /usr/local/bin/gcc-4.2 cc
sudo ln -s /usr/local/bin/gcc-4.2 gcc
sudo ln -s /usr/local/bin/c++-4.2 c++
sudo ln -s /usr/local/bin/g++-4.2 g++

If your gcc-4.2 is in a different location you can find that location by running these commands.

which gcc-4.2
which c++-4.2
which g++-4.2

Setup Riak

Now we’re set to follow the Riak instructions for setup. They are explained in more detail in the Riak Quickstart.

cd riak-1.4.8
make all
make devrel DEVNODES=5
cd dev
ulimit -n 4096
for node in `ls`; do $node/bin/riak start; done
for node in `ls`; do $node/bin/riak ping; done
for n in {2..5}; do dev$n/bin/riak-admin cluster join dev1@127.0.0.1; done
dev1/bin/riak-admin cluster plan
dev1/bin/riak-admin cluster commit
dev1/bin/riak-admin member-status

Now we have a Riak cluster!

Any errors are available by running something like dev1/bin/riak console. dev1 is for the first node. It would be dev2 for the second node and so forth. If you didn’t use gcc-4.2 and a R15B01 64-bit build of Erlang you might have received an error that looked like this:

16:55:17.552 [error] Error loading "erlang_js_drv": "dlopen(/Users/catchvar/Workspace/riak-1.4.8/dev/dev1/bin/../lib/erlang_js-1.2.2/priv/erlang_js_drv.so, 2): no suitable image found.  Did find:\n\t/Users/catchvar/Workspace/riak-1.4.8/dev/dev1/bin/../lib/erlang_js-1.2.2/priv/erlang_js_drv.so: mach-o, but wrong architecture"

16:55:17.552 [error] CRASH REPORT Process erlang_js_sup with 0 neighbours exited with reason: bad return value: {error,{load_error,"Failed to load erlang_js_drv.so"}} in gen_server:init_it/6 line 332
16:55:17.552 [error] CRASH REPORT Process <0.115.0> with 0 neighbours exited with reason: bad return value: {error,{load_error,"Failed to load erlang_js_drv.so"}} in erlang_js:start(normal, []) in application_master:init/4 line 138
16:55:17.552 [info] Application erlang_js exited with reason: bad return value: {error,{load_error,"Failed to load erlang_js_drv.so"}} in erlang_js:start(normal, [])
{"Kernel pid terminated",application_controller,"{application_start_failure,erlang_js,},{erlang_js,start,[normal,[]]}}}"}

Setup Erlang Client

Not everybody is using Erlang. If you’re using another language you can find a list of clients here. Setup for the erlang-riak-client is pretty straightforward. The only problem I ran into is that it doesn’t support Erlang 17.0-RC2, and won’t build if you’re using that version of Erlang. Keep using R15B01 and you should be good.

cd /path/to/your/erlang/project
cd deps
git clone git://github.com/basho/riak-erlang-client.git
cd riak-erlang-client
make

When you run Erlang you need to add riak-erlang-client to it’s code path. I have a shell script called debug.sh in my /ebin folder with the following contents:

erl -pa `pwd` ../deps/*/ebin ../deps/riak-erlang-client/deps/*/ebin -boot start_sasl -s rinoa_app

Run debug.sh, press enter and you can test out a connection to the Riak cluster.

sh debug.sh

{ok, Pid} = riakc_pb_socket:start_link("127.0.0.1", 10017).
riakc_pb_socket:ping(Pid).

To figure out if your port is different than 10017:

cd riak-1.4.8/dev
cat dev1/etc/app.config

Towards the top you’ll see some configuration that looks like this:

%% pb is a list of IP addresses and TCP ports that the Riak
%% Protocol Buffers interface will bind.
{pb, [ {"127.0.0.1", 10017 } ]}

That’s it. I hope that was helpful to someone.

entry.title: Catchvar - Game Design and The Ideal World
entry.content:
Game Design and The Ideal World

- Mar 9, 2014 -

I don’t believe that people ask why people play games often enough.

There is an extensive amount of material related to game design on the internet. Most of this material I have found falls broadly into one of two categories. The first category is bullet-point lists. These typically are one-size fits all recommendations based on observations from a successful game. These can be useful. We should always study and learn from the successes and failures around us. However, general recommendations usually fail to capture the complicated context in which they apply.

The second category is more useful and consists of in depth analysis about what design should be like, and how we can further improve the gaming experience for users. I personally want games to be of benefit to players, and find myself in disagreement with many of the mechanics that make it into today’s casual social games. However, much of the material that falls into this category fails to account for both what gamers consider a good game and why so many people also love casual social games. The explanation is often that casual social games are just plain manipulative. They are. But maybe there is something deeper that explains why people play these games.

The Why of Game Design

We need a new theory on game design that goes further than Minecraft good, Farmville bad. My view is that games are ultimately a reflection of the ideal world. Games fill some void that is present in reality and at any given time the perfect game allows a person to live the life they really want to live.

You might be thinking, “Wait a minute! I don’t want to be pig farmer! And if you’re right I’ll just create a game where you have infinite fame and money and kill all enemies with the flick of a wrist. Muahahaha…”.

People are more complex than that. The perfect world is not full of rainbows and lollipops where nothing goes wrong. That type of world may be fun for a short while, but I bet that most people would quickly become bored. Similarly, the ideal world for a person may have very little to do with their profession and surroundings. Although, I must admit that my favorite games have some sort of fantasy theme where I can beat down monsters with swords and magic.

So what is the ideal world? What life attributes are necessary for a person to be upon and their deathbed and confidently say that they led a life fulfilled and satisfied? It’s likely different for each and every person. However, there are certain qualities that many seek in their professional and personal lives that all common among the best games. I’ll update this list as I come across more qualities. For now, I believe that every human strives for challenge, progression, understanding, freedom, and socialization.

Challenge

Challenge is one of the most obvious aspects to any game. Even in the most vapid and humdrum games you must endure the mental challenge of patience. Otherwise the game would end instanteously. The challenge can also take on many other forms. It could be figuring out where to go next, solving a puzzle, finding out how fast you can button mash, or showing emotional resilience in the game that kills you 70 times a minute.

People need challenge. Maybe not 24/7. But, whether it is due to evolution, divine will, coded into our genes, or all three, people need challenge. Without a challenge you get boredom. Johnathan Blow, the creator of braid, said in one of his talks:

Boredom is a healthy response to unproductive situations… Boredom has survival value.

He was talking about how social games manipulate people into overcoming their natural survival instincts. If boredom has survival value it is to point people towards a challenge. That is why humans keep advancing and surviving. Because we need a challenge. If you cannot get your challenge in the real world, then perhaps you would turn to games. Now, challenge is not something that everybody is missing from their lives. It is however, linked to our next quality.

Progression

This is the quality probably most associated with gamificiation, social games, and familiar to all gamers. You beat a level to get to the next level, or you kill monsters to gain experience points, or you get more stuff to add to your house. This is a reflection of real-life. People go to school to increase their grade. Seniors are always cooler than Freshman. People get a degree, maybe two, to prove their qualifications and to gain more knowledge. People work to get a bigger salary, faster cars, and a bigger house (or a house at all).

Not everybody makes progress in life. Or maybe not in the way they expect themselves to. A housewife that feels stuck in life might gain solace with the occasional Candycrush and Farmville because they can always get better. They can always improve their skill, or gain better decorations. Maybe you’re doing just fine in life and you just want to make more progress crushing some n00bs in Starcraft.

That last paragraph was kind of a downer now that I wrote it, but I think it’s necessary to examine why games are attractive. On to the next quality.

Understanding

The world is a complex and complicated place. Interactions can have ripple effects that make it seem like things just happen for no reason. Philosophers and religion have been trying to explain the world for thousands of years. Even with as much as we have learned there is just so much missing. Why are we here? What is our purpose in life? Will choosing bacon, steak, or both for dinner have profound unknown effects that cause the world to end in fifty years? I just don’t know.

Games offer a much simpler world. In Mario if you get hit by an enemy or fall in a hole you die. If you get a powerup it has a deterministic bonus that helps you kill baddies. If you reach the end of the level you win. Even in a more complex rpg scenario the world is easy to understand. These stats effect my damage this much. I have an x% chance of evading an attack. If I get these items with these stats I can maximize the amount of damage I can inflict while still surviving assuming the enemies dps is exactly this much.

This also explains why players just don’t care for extremely complicated simulation effects. They just don’t understand them, and therefore they don’t contribute to their play.

Freedom

Sometimes people want to do whatever the heck they want to. In the real world your freedom is restricted by many things. It could be that your freedom is restricted by money, social obligations, or even family obligations. We also have many rules in place. Most of them for good reason, in order to maintain a society that can flourish and thrive. For example, there are good rules in place that prevent you from dual-wielding poison infused daggers and ganking somebody when they least expect it. Even further, people are restricted by what is actually possible with our current technology. I can’t fly un-aided through a snowy mountain range.

Games provide a way to experience what it might be like to circumvent all of these restrictions. In some ways being able to magically gain money by killing a creature is a form of freedom. You can become a goblin rampaging through the hills. You can experience fantastic worlds made of candy and chocolate. One of the most popular games to exemplify this quality is Minecraft. By now most everybody has heard of Minecraft, and on mobile it’s less popular Survivalcraft clone. It’s a voxel-based game that let’s you build anything you can image out of blocks. It’s a great expression of freedom and allows the player to do things they could never imagine in the real world.

Socialization

Not all games satisfy this quality, but on some level or another everybody requires or desires some sort of interaction with other people. Even if you imagine yourself to be an introvert, spending a month in absolute seclusion can drive a man mad. Before the internet, games could be played together as a way to pass the time, laugh, or get to know somebody better. Since the invention of the internet, people have been able to more or less the same without being in the same room. This makes some people cringe, and evokes images of a computer nerd sitting in the dark pretending to be a girl over the internet.

Like many things in the world there are pros and cons. It could give you a chance to interact with real-life friends that are too far away to visit on a daily basis. When I was a teenager I had a friend that I moved away from. We kept in touch by playing Dark Age of Camelot over the internet. For those of you that are not familiar with the game it’s an mmorpg that both preceded and is very similar to WoW. We would be on Ventrilo talking over our mics as we went on a raid, or did some PvP. It was pretty fun.

You might even be able to make the argument that someone could build leadership skills in a mmorpg. Hear me out here. I’m not saying that someone who has played an mmorpg can go and lead a company. Not even close. However organizing people, recuiting people, convincing them to follow a purpose, like the leader of a guild would do, certainly has its merits. Especially if that person wouldn’t be exposed to those experiences otherwise.

Conclusion

Hopefully, I have presented enough loose evidence to support that the qualities of challenge, progression, understanding, freedom, and socialization are all qualities that we look for in our everyday lives. When we aren’t able to satisfy these qualities it’s possible that we use games as an outlet to fulfill that missing satisfaction. This does not meaning getting sucked into a game and losing yourself. It could. It could also mean just relieving a little stress with thirty minutes of play.

I’m not trying to argue whether some games are good or bad. By understanding why people play games it provides a better starting point for how you construct your games. Also understand that manipulation in itself is not bad. It has just received a negative connotation over time. Manipulation is just understanding the underlying mechanics that affect behaviour and optimizing for a desired goal. The goal you aim for is what makes a valiant or devious effort. There is no reason to prevent putting eye candy into a game because it’s manipulative if you’re optimizing for a better experience.

The next time you see some horrible social game that you hate get really popular, you shouldn’t rage and be like, “Argh! They’re ruining games!”. You should give thought to why that game became popular in the first place. I don’t mean copying elements from that game and putting it into your game. Really ask yourself, “Why?”. It could be because it fulfilled the basic qualities of life that we need in order to be satisfied.
